Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2563 Thursday, 20 October 1994 Consideration resumed from 13 October. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. This bill presents amendments necessary to implement the remaining part of the budget package for the veterans' affairs portfolio. Honourable members will recall that the first part of the package was dealt with by the parliament in the winter sittings. In developing this package extensive, constructive and valuable consultations with the ex-service community were held by me and my predecessor, Senator Faulkner. These consultations were welcomed by both the government and the ex-service community and it is my hope that we may continue to work together in the future to provide the best possible care and recognition for veterans and their dependants. The budget package was developed to address the most pressing needs of ex-servicemen and women, war widows and widowers and their dependants. It responded to issues raised by Professor Peter Baume, Air Vice-Marshal Richard Bomball and Ms Robyn Layton in their report entitled A Fair Go. It also responded to issues raised by other groups in respect of the ageing of veterans of the world wars, and the different set of difficulties facing younger veterans. I will now tum to the specific measures included in this bill. The first initiative will affect service pensioners and income support supplement recipients. The treatment of their compensation payments, such as accident, sickness and workers compensation payments, will be aligned with the way in which compensation payments received by recipients of comparable social security payments are treated under the Social Security Act. This will ensure equitable assessment of income support payments made by both departments. Without going into detail, receipt of compensation payments may affect the rate and payability of service pension and income support supplement. The purpose of these provisions is to prevent double dipping. They only apply where a person receives a compensation payment which includes a component for loss of earnings or loss of the capacity to earn, and then only if the service pension or income support supplement recipient is under pension age. The new arrangements will only apply to compensation payments received on or after 1 January 1995. Pensions that are not for income support are not included in these new arrangements. Already a person in receipt of disability pension or war widows or widowers pension may have the rate of that pension reduced if the compensation payments are paid in respect of the same injury or disease for which the pension is being paid. Thus, in the case of a person who receives both a disability pension and service pension, any compensation payments which have been used to reduce the payment of the disability pension will not be taken into account again
title: Auditor General S Reports

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Jenkins) Took The Chair At 10.00 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Sciacca (Bowman
theText: Minister for Veterans' Affairs) (10.00 a.m.)-I move:2564 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 to affect the payment of a person's service pension. Similar arrangements will also apply to a person in receipt of both a war widows or widowers pension and income support supplement. The next initiative provides automatic eligibility for a funeral benefit to be paid to the estate of a veteran who, at the time of death, was receiving extreme disablement adjustment or was a former prisoner of war. In a large percentage of such cases a funeral benefit would be paid under the existing rules, but not automatically. In many cases these veterans leave behind a grieving partner, who will no longer need to forward an application in that time of grief, nor will the partner suffer any anxiety about the availability of the benefit. Automatic eligibility for funeral benefit already applies to certain other groups of pensioners. The addition of these new groups will provide uniformity by granting a funeral benefit in all cases in which an automatic grant of war widows or widowers pension applies. Another initiative in this bill will be of benefit to applicants to the Veterans Review Board. Until now they may have had to meet certain costs of obtaining medical evidence to submit to the board out of their own pocket. Now they will be reimbursed those costs. They will be entitled to payment of an amount up to $425 for each condition subject to review, as well as an allowance for associated travelling expenses. Already the cost of certain medical evidence obtained at the primary determining level may be reimbursed. The introduction of this change is in response to a recommendation of the Baume committee. I expect that it will encourage applicants to present their supporting evidence as soon as they can. Currently some applicants appear to withhold evidence until it can be presented at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because in some cases such costs can be met through legal aid grants. By meeting some or all of the costs involved in obtaining this evidence at an earlier stage, it is possible that a decision in favour of the applicant may be recorded earlier. This would avoid the need for many applicants to pursue an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A further initiative will allow for the payment of an education entry payment to partner and carer service pensioners and to income support supplement recipients. Education entry payments are paid annually to meet some of the costs of enrolling in a course of study. They assist pensioners under pension age to further their education, thereby improving their employment prospects. The next initiative is of particular benefit to refugees. It will remove the waiting period for service pension for those Commonwealth veterans, allied veterans and allied mariners who were given permanent resident status as refugees. They will no longer need to have been Australian residents for a continuous period of 10 years nor will they need to meet the rules for non-continuous periods. These requirements are being eased because refugees, unlike other migrants, do not have a choice when leaving their home countries. They also experience greater resettlement difficulties and are less likely to obtain a pension from their countries of origin. I am informed that this initiative has been warmly received within those segments of our multicultural society where refugees are represented. Another initiative will mean that pharmaceutical allowance will be paid only to a person who is in Australia. Short-term absences, however, will not be taken into account. Pharmaceutical allowance was introduced in 1990 to compensate pensioners for the cost of prescription items supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and later the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. These prescription items had previously been free of charge. Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMfITEE 2565 A further proposal in this bill affects membership of the Veterans Review Board. The requirement that a proportion of the members of the Veterans Review Board be registered or licensed medical practitioners will be removed. This is consequential upon the establishment of the Repatriation Medical Authority and the Specialist Medical Review Council under the first part of the budget measures package. The Repatriation Medical Authority determines questions of medical causation and prepares statements of principle. These are based on sound medical scientific evidence and exclusively state what factors related to service must exist to establish a causal connection between particular diseases, injuries or death and service. A right of appeal against certain determinations of the Repatriation Medical Authority is available to the Specialist Medical Review Council. The proposal does not affect the terms of appointment of the current medical members nor will it alter the total number of members. Persons with medical qualifications could still be appointed as ordinary members. This bill also contains consequential amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act and other acts relating to matters dealt with in the first Act of the package. The consequential amendments relate to the payment of income support supplement, the payment of 'single' rate service pension to widows, widowers and non-illness separated spouses, and the integration of Australian mariners with veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. In summary, I believe that the measures presented in this Bill represent major initiatives which will help to ensure the fair and equitable delivery of repatriation benefits to veterans and their dependants. I commend the bill to the House. Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill, but I must express disappointment again as to the period of time made available to me for consultation as the opposition's representative of veterans and other people affected by these decisions. It was our understanding, just a few days ago, that this bill would come on for debate in November, and we were informing the various veterans' organisations accordingly. It does create problems, which I do not think are necessary, considering that most of these measures will not be implemented until next calendar year anyway. I see my role in representing the interests of veterans in this place as one of advocacy and of achieving the best result wherever possible by negotiation with the government. I think we have already proved our credentials in that regard. However, in legislation of this type there are aspects that could require reading by people of considerable experience in veterans' affairs. For example, it could be that tucked away in one of these bills is something that a person with a long experience in negotiating with the government would recognise as an issue that had been opposed in the past. I know that I need the help of people who have spent decades, in some cases, representing the interests of veterans. In the context of the excellent relationship we have had on these issues to date, I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs( Mr Sciacca) that I would appreciate more time. I rushed into my party room on Monday before I had even put the matter to the shadow ministry. The party room took the attitude that we would reserve our right to introduce further amendments to this legislation in the Senate if some specific issue arose. I am not contemplating that this situation need occur but we are of the view that we must take that particular position. I have had a chance since then to talk with the various interest groups. This is the problem when bills are introduced one week and debated the next.
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Tuckey (O'connor) (10.09 A.m.)
theText: The coalition is not opposed to the Veterans'2566 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 This is my first time in the Main Committee. I argued quite passionately for its establishment because I expected that the Main Committee would avoid the outcome of guillotines and legislative log jams at the end of session. As I have said time and again, I can cop the cut in speaking time but, as a frontbencher, I cannot support a concept of being given insufficient time to consult with interest groups outside this parliament. I want to put that on the record. I advise the Main Committee that we do have one amendment which I will refer to later. This has been circulated in my name. I point out to the minister that we were only able to fax that amendment to him last night for the simple reason that we did not have adequate time. If the minister wants us to advise him of our intentions in adequate time for him to provide a response, he should recognise that more time is necessary. In my view, the minister has given a fair interpretation of this legislation in his second reading speech. I make some remarks in that regard. It is a sensible proposition that the alignment of compensation payments-where they apply on an income related basis-is practical and fair. As the minister has pointed out, it is already in effect in other areas. It does not affect disability payments directly or people over the pension age. That is an attractive and proper situation. It is a little complex in some cases. Disability payments will be affected but there will be no effect on pensions. On most occasions, I would expect the opposite to apply. As a consequence, I hope the department makes sure that veterans are properly informed as to how this measure will apply to them. It is quite proper that, if somebody is getting compensation on the basis of another injury, they should not be able to double dip, as the minister says. I welcome the introduction of automatic payments of funeral benefits to the estate of a veteran who is receiving extreme disablement adjustment or who was a former prisoner of war. Over time, I hope that this assistance can be expanded further. I certainly welcome the fact that it has been made automatic. It is easy to say that something is automatic but there must be some process by which the funeral director or whoever can seek this assistance. I would like the minister to explain this in his response so we can tell people the process. 'Automatic' is an interesting word. If the department is not aware of someone's death, I am not sure how it can make an automatic payment. The department might not happen to read about it in the papers. The process is probably covered by administrative arrangements. I would like to know what these arrangements are so the matter can be well and truly circulated. I now turn to the issue of reimbursement of costs for applicants obtaining medical evidence to present to the Veterans Review Board-a maximum amount of $425 for each condition. We welcome the government's decision. It is not a great cost. My recollection is that the estimated cost to government is about $40,000. That is very small beer when one considers that it will assist veterans who would not otherwise have the financial resources to do it. I support the minister's view that, if these matters can be resolved at the level of the VRB, that is preferable to going to the AAT, with all the associated costs of legal representation. Members of the veterans community still have grave doubts because many of their appeal processes do not involve legal representation. We have to have faith that the VRB, the Specialist Medical Review Council and other bodies are going to be generous to veterans because they do not have legal representation in these areas. The reduction in cost, both to individual veterans and to the department, is a matter which I think should be avoided. Provided the veteran appellant is in a position to be guaranteed a fair deal, it is much better that we go down that road. I am quite willing to try to convince concerned veterans that it Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2567 is an appropriate process. My efforts will be substantiated if the government ensures that if there is a doubt it comes down on the side of the veteran. That is the area of concern. In making what is a quite proper decision, and for reasons that the minister has announced, I feel-and I hope that I am correct-that the government overlooked the newly established Specialist Medical Review Council, which would probably be used a lot less often than the VRB. The amendment that I have circulated in my name today seeks to give the same financial assistance to people seeking or having to obtain medical evidence to go before that Specialist Medical Review Council as to those to go before the VRB. Quite clearly, that is what the provision is there for and medical evidence would obviously be the determinant. It could be that because of the significant nature of it-we are talking about something that could consequently affect a lot of other veterans-that $425 would be a minimal amount because the veteran would probably have to mount an even more substantial case in terms of arguing for an additional SOP, for instance. There may be some argument that the amount should be more, but we have suggested that whilst people appealing to the VRB would now have this financial assistance, it should be extended to those appealing to the Specialist Medical Review Council. It may be that, under the new rules of the VRB, medical evidence may not be so necessary, simply because the SOPs are binding on the VRB-and there will be less medical debate, quite obviously. I do not actually understand how much medical evidence a veteran might still have to put before the VRB, but obviously there will be some, and it will cost the individual veteran money to obtain that advice and that report. It is an excellent idea to give some financial assistance, both in terms of paying for the medical advice and for any travel associated with that medical advice. As I have informed the minister, we will only move these amendments in this House. They are amendments to the act-as is the rest of this bill-and they have been inserted in the appropriate section dealing with the Specialist Medical Review Council. I might point out to the minister that, whilst an opposition generally cannot commit a government to expenditure, he has a one-line item in his budget of $4.671 million-which is to be found in Appropriation Bill (No.1), under the schedule for Veterans' Affairs, division 195, item 4-03-which clearly could be applied to this purpose. So we are not asking the government to alter its budget-just to find what might be a very small amount of money when one looks at $120 billion of expenditure, to extend the government's generosity, in terms of the VRB, to applicants to the SMRC. It might be that the government is able to announce, prior to this matter being debated in the Senate, or even today, that it will accept our amendments and have them passed with the support of all members of the House of Representatives and/or the Senate. I foreshadow that I will move our amendments in the consideration in detail stage. That is a matter of importance. I note the government's intention to introduce an education entry payment to partner and carer service pensioners and income support supplement recipients. That is, as we interpret it, about $200. I am not sure that that is going to be a great help. I wholeheartedly support the concept of giving financial assistance to people to educate themselves so they can re-enter the work force. I am wondering just how much encouragement $200 might be, but it is a step in the right direction, so we are not opposing it. 2568 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 I might add, in the context of educating people and getting them back into the work force, that the government, some time ago, invited here two people from Massachusetts in America. They were employees of one-time presidential aspirant Mr Michael Dukakis, in his position as governor of Massachusetts. In our terminology, the male was head of the social security department and the female, who also happened to be his wife, was head of the CES. They were brought out here to give advice on getting single parents back into the work force. I was fortunate enough to attend a briefing they gave to interested members and staff. I was extremely disappointed, although I predicted it at the time, that the real grounds for their success-and they are internationally recognised for it-were ignored by this government. Basically, they are still ignored, notwithstanding the move to case management and things that appear in the white paper. It is something the minister, having an interest as declared here under this announcement, might like to lead his party on. When the husband took over social security, he realised that he was paying a large number of people who, in fact, had university qualifications and all sorts of things but had got sidelined as single parents and could not get back into the work force, and that he had a responsibility to do something about that. What he did was ring up his wife, and a number of private agencies, and say, 'I have a deal for you.' It is quite typical of the way Americans, even in a bureaucracy, manage to do business. The deal was simply this: he put a price on getting those people back into the work force in permanent employment. Whether it was his wife's department-the CES, as we would know it here-or certain approved private agencies, people would say, 'Yes, I will take Joe Blow on. I will re-educate him and brush up his present qualifications, find him a job and keep him in it for whatever is the agreed period. Then you will pay me the money, as a lump sum.' It is the incentive of that that has made that scheme work. All the bits and pieces that went around the periphery of that were listened to by the government. But the government ignored that fundamental: that people-even other government departments-were given a financial incentive only if they succeeded. Whether we like it or not, it is a fundamental of human nature and it is working in Massachusetts. Nevertheless, the $200 is a step in the right direction. I think it is also fair and reasonable to remove the waiting period for service pensions for refugees. The minister's arguments are quite clear there. It is a specialist area and we are presuming people are refugees who have fought in their own country, and possibly fought on our side in some particular conflict, and they should get the recognition they deserve. The cessation of payments for pharmaceutical allowances for veterans who are absent from Australia for a period of 12 months or more is also supported. We are talking about $2.60 per individual or $5.20 per married couple that was provided by the government when it commenced the ever growing process of charging up-front fees on medical prescriptions that previously were issued absolutely free of charge. This fortnightly payment is aimed at compensating pensioners, on an averaging basis, for that additional cost. We see that as quite an appropriate measure and in fact we do not see why people who are living in another country and dealing with the pharmaceutical system that applies in that country should be receiving benefits from Australia. So we support the government in removing that benefit from people who no longer go into our pharmacies and who are acquiring pharmaceutical prescriptions anyway. Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 2569 Other than the consequential amendments, the final major issue is the removal of the requirement that a proportion of the members of the Veterans Review Board be registered or licensed medical practitioners. This makes sense. We now have the Repatriation Medical Authority. We have the binding of the VRB to its statement of principles. The idea of certain members of the board turning to someone else and saying, 'Well, has that medical evidence got any standing', because they as lay persons would not know, is no longer necessary. They are tied to the SOPs and we hope by the time they have passed the parliament they will be concise and reasonably understandable, so there is no reason to have specialist type people on the VRB. I note that the minister points out some will probably remain as ordinary members and that makes sense, but over the years if we do not need these people and others can do the job equally well, then why not have them there. We have not got any serious concerns that I am aware of in any of those issues. Having a few minutes left, I might point out to the minister that he may at some time in the future-and the recent Agent Orange arrangement highlights this-find that he is very grateful to the coalition for putting forward the amendment to which he agreed, to create an appeal provision in the Specialist Medical Review Council. I say that because we have a classic example here of evidence coming forward to the minister of a change in medical opinion on the effects of herbicides, in this case Agent Orange, for causal effects in terms of a present medical condition of veterans, and in this case, those who were in the Vietnam war. The simple fact is that by creating the Repatriation Medical Authority the minister is no longer able to make a commitment to veterans to the effect that he will fix it. All he or any future minister can do is refer that medical evidence to the RMA and ask it to make a decision. I cannot see how else it will work because it has to come down with a statement of principle and, if the minister is going to overrule it on those sorts of things, then we might ask what it is doing. Why not just write the statement of principles in the minister's office. There might be some little legal remedy there that gets around it but I doubt that the minister should use it if he is going to stand by what he did. The simple fact is that a person has the right to appeal to the Specialist Medical Review Council that we created. As I see it, one could probably put the two professors who wrote the report on that particular Specialist Medical Review Council because that is wide open to appointments from time to time. As I said to the minister at the time, we might be just saving him from himself. I am quite happy to repeat that remark but I am also prepared to say that the minister and his office gave us the maximum cooperation in considering that matter and it was resolved in the proper way in the interests of veterans. I say to the minister, in concluding, that I want to take this opportunity to mention representations I received recently. I do not want to mention the person's name, but I will naturally provide it to the minister. I have had drawn to my attention the psychological effect that PTSD has on veterans. The problems associated with it are a matter that the minister is concerned about. I am concerned about it. I am also concerned about the attitudes of others whom I consulted this week about how we should deal with people with psychological problems. The out-sourcing that has gone on in recent times, particularly at state level, has gone too far. I cannot stand up as an expert with solutions, but institutionalisation has received a lot of criticism. On the other hand, to throw some of these people out on the street without proper support is equally bad, in my mind. When I had this case drawn to my attention, it really did worry me. 2570 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 The person I am talking about enlisted in World War II at the age of 14. He then went away as a soldier, and later served in Korea and Vietnam. He is now in an advanced stage of all sorts of illnesses, including Huntington's syndrome, but is required to continue living at home, presumably with the assistance of his daughter. He has organic brain disease, renal failure and PTSD muscle spasms, and is being harassed by the police. According to my advice, he is a prisoner in his own home because when he walks outside he worries people. He possibly does do violent things on the street. He has had restraining orders put upon him. His neighbours belittle him and, apparently, have told him to go back in the house and die. It is a pretty sad case. I want to put it on the record, not in any form of criticism, but because something has got to be done. I will hand his name and address to the minister. He has been in and out of the courts and I am not saying he did not do something that the broader community would say is wrong. Apparently he is seriously ill, having given service in all the areas I have mentioned. He is now aged 67, and I think we need to investigate the matter in order to help this person in what might be his remaining months. I thank the minister for taking note of this matter. I know I will get a response. I think it is sufficiently serious to raise in this place. When the information was put before me, it really got me down. We do not oppose this legislation. We would welcome the government's supporting us in what we think is something it possibly overlooked in its proposals to give financial assistance to people making appeals to the VRB, assistance which is also needed on the occasions when they go to the Specialist Medical Review Council. have this opportunity to rise in support of the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2). Issues of importance to our veterans community are about to gain an added impetus at the Australian remembrance campaign next year when matters of concern to veterans will be highlighted. It is timely that we are talking about veterans issues with this particular bill. The bill proposes a number of amendments necessary to implement the second stage of the budget package for the veterans' affairs portfolio. Members will be well acquainted with the broad range of measures which the budget brought down to improve things for veterans. The initiatives contained in the budget, and in this bill, have been developed to address the most pressing needs of ex-servicemen and women, war widows and widowers, and their dependants. The package responds in a real way to the issues raised by the Baume committee and other groups with respect to problems of older veterans of the two world wars, and the problems of younger veterans of more recent conflicts. Following the budget, the RSL National President, Major General 'Digger' James, endorsed the Veterans' Affairs package. It is fair to say that the RSL and Labor governments have not always seen eye-to-eye in the past-and still do not, on certain issues-but the reception of the budget package is due in no small way to the role of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs( Mr Sciacca) in gaining the support of the veterans community and its peak bodies. I congratulate him on his efforts since becoming minister. He was actually in my electorate on business on Friday of last week, and he visited the Amberley RAAF base to have a look around there. He spoke about some things for the Australian remembrance campaign next year. He was good enough to give up his time to meet with three of my veteran constituents-very important people in our community. I would like to say something about these three particular
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Les Scott (Oxley) (10.34 A.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I am particularly pleased toThursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2571 people. They are actually from the Veterans Support and Advocacy Service, which is located in Inala, in the electorate of the honourable member for Rankin( Mr Beddall). They come from three different areas and I will speak of them in a minute. The secretary, of course, is from my own electorate. I would like to take the opportunity to formally place on the record my appreciation to the minister for giving up his time last week to meet with these three veterans, who are actually Vietnam veterans, and with the other Ipswich veterans he met earlier this year when he visited the electorate not long after being given the portfolio. I understand that the Goodna RSL Club was the first place that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs actually visited after becoming minister. He went over particularly well, and sat and spoke with members of our veteran community, and they were very pleased. The three gentlemen to whom I referred a moment ago as having spoken to the minister last week are Brian Evans, who lives in Ipswich in my electorate; Paul McPhee, who lives in the electorate of the honourable member for Fadden( Mr Jull); and Brett Kriewaldt, the president of the association, who lives in the electorate of the Attorney-General( Mr Lavarch), who is the honourable member for Dickson. All three gentlemen are very keen to get involved in the Australian remembrance campaign next year, and I look forward to their contribution. Brian will certainly be involved in my own local electorate, and Paul and Brett in the electorates of the members. I referred to before. The Veterans Support and Advocacy Service has been centralised very much on the needs of Vietnam veterans. I remember that Brian Evans came to see me some time ago, before he was involved with this particular service. He was certainly someone who was very severely affected by the stress of the war. It is only since he has become involved with the service that he has come out of that. It has been a great transformation to see Brian become such a great worker for his fellow veterans. He is doing a tremendous job. I would like to put that on the record, because it really goes to show how the support that people can get from one another helps so much, and his is a real case in point. During the minister's visit to my electorate last week, he discussed a range of issues with the members from the Veterans Support and Advocacy Service, issues which are important to all members of the veterans community and not just to the Vietnam veterans. They do not distinguish between them: a veteran is a veteran, as far as the service is concerned, no matter what conflict the veteran was involved in. The service provides a much-needed focal point for veterans in the whole Ipswich-Inala region. It is particularly the younger veterans that these people concentrate on. They have already gained much from the budget measures, and that is why I mentioned Brian Evans's own stress related problems before. The post-traumatic stress disorder package introduced earlier this year was covered by the Baume committee. It was certainly welcomed very much by the whole veterans community, and was an innovative package that I was particularly pleased about, since there are quite a number of Vietnam veterans in my own electorate who will benefit from that $20.6 million over four years. Anyone who has been dealing with sufferers of this condition knows how demoralising it can be, both to the sufferer and to his or her family. That is something that we all, as members of parliament, can look at with very much a bipartisan attitude. I am sure that most members of the House have dealings with the whole range of veterans, including Vietnam veterans, and that they see these problems for themselves. I welcome the initiative, which includes funding for the PTSD treatment centres, more resources for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, and money for research into the specific health 2572 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 problems of younger veterans-such as the Agent Orange problem which the honourable member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey) talked about before. This bill adds to that excellent package of reform measures. It is certainly wide in its scope, but I would like to concentrate on a few areas in the time allocated to me today. Firstly, the bill will amend the act to align the treatment of compensation payments received by service pensioners with the way in which compensation payment recipients of comparable social security payments are treated under the Social Security Act. At the moment, compensation payments to service pensioners are treated in a number of ways. Periodic payments of compensation are treated as income for the purposes of the ordinary income test. Lump sum compensation payments are held as an asset of the person, and any income derived from that asset is then treated as ordinary income for the purposes of the ordinary income test. If people receive compensation and part of that compensation is made for loss of earnings or loss of capacity to earn, they are not entitled to a service pension in addition to the compensation payment they have already received. The important thing to note here is that veterans are not looking for handouts or special charity provisions. I can safely say that the veterans in my electorate, and in the broader community, are the sort of people who like to think of themselves as members of the community who pull their weight in our society. They are people who have reaIly pulled their weight more than many others in our community, so I do not think too many of them would disagree with this amendment which rationalises and streamlines the veterans entitlements process. One of the other amendments deals with the income support supplement, known as ISS, which was also introduced with the budget measures this year. The bill aims to extend the ISS to war widows or widowers who are caring for severely handicapped persons. This is another compassionate and worthwhile initiative for veterans and their dependants. We should remember that wars are fought not only on the battlefields but also in the homes of Australiaby the wives and families who are left behind. That is something that we will remember very much, I believe, in 1995 in the Australia Remembers program. It is really the families who are very severely affected. The wives, families and children are all very much affected by war and need to have a lot of assistance and compassion afforded to them. Those who were left behind when their loved ones served their country overseas are those important people we speak about, and I do not think there are too many people in this country who have not been affected in some small way by those sorts of situations. The majority of voluntary caring work in our society is done by women-I think we all know that-and it is something that should always be acknowledged whenever possible in this place. This extension of income support supplement is targeted at them, and rightly so. Caring for a handicapped or elderly person is one of the most selfless tasks one human being can perform for another, but it is also one of the most demanding. When we talk to people who are affected in this way, when we see an older couple where a male veteran is deteriorating in his later years, it is very often the wife who is giving a lot of that support that he needs. Women are the unsung heroes of many of our conflicts. Their physical and emotional reserves are called upon every day to face the challenge of caring for people who are sometimes terribly afflicted. I am very pleased that this initiative is being introduced in National Carers Week. The ISS itself was another of the excellent reforming initiatives contained in the original legislation earlier this year. As members may remember, it will be introduced in March next Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 2573 year. The change will affect widows and widowers who, in addition to their war widows or widowers pension, also receive additional income support payments from the Department of Social Security. Before the legislation was introduced, widows and widowers have had to collect this pension through DSS, but under new plans introduced by the minister they will receive the income support supplement directly from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This wiII no doubt make life a lot easier for recipients, and it will certainly make life simpler for the group of people who will be regarded as eligible for the ISS. The payment will be paid at the same rate as the social security payment, and veterans entitled to the payment who wish to continue to receive their payment through the Department of Social Security may elect to do so. The ISS initiative has been warmly received by the ex-service community in general and the War Widows Guild in particular. It is estimated that nearly 54,000 war widows and widowers will elect to transfer this payment from DSS to Veterans' Affairs, and I am sure life will be a lot easier and simpler for them as a result of that. This bill also seeks to extend the education entry payment to ISS recipients. Education entry payments are made to some pensioners to help them further their education and thus enhance their job prospects. The payment is an annual grant made to assist with the costs of enrolling in a course of study. The amendments provide that partner and carer service pensioners may be paid an education entry payment in certain circumstances, namely, if they are below pension age and if they are qualified to receive pensioner education supplement under the Austudy scheme. I think it is important to realise that education is becoming a commodity more valuable than anyone could have imagined even 20 years ago and that it is not restricted to younger people; older people can benefit from the new technologies as well and that is something we really should focus a lot more on. In today's world of rapidly changing technology everyone should have access to the means to stay well informed and up to date. Education is the best way to do this, and that goes for the veteran community as well as everyone else. It is not always elderly people either but people around the age of the minister and me-we do not really call ourselves elderly at this stage but it certainly affects a lot of us. Many elderly people would have been denied opportunities that the present generation of tertiary students has come to take for granted. One of the best ways of encouraging a healthy retirement is to have an interest that exercises the body and the mind. The number of mature age students at universities these days is proof of that and should be very welcome. However, many older veterans and dependants would encounter some difficulty in enrolling in tertiary courses because of the cost factor. This amendment will help this group of people and should be welcomed. The amendment is timely, coming as it does two days after the Creative Nation statement presented by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) earlier this week, which has been well received across the nation. It contained many initiatives in the field of technological education. We all realise the importance of having access to, and an understanding of, the technology that is already transforming our world and will change it further in the years to come. It should not be seen as merely a young person's preserve. The elderly need to know about community services, government programs and anything else that the information highway will contain, so they will need to know how to use this sort of technology as well as their grandchildren do. It is amazing how people can respond to that new technology. 2574 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 I am pleased to have had the opportunity to support this legislation today this Main Committee room with its closeness and friendliness. I support the bill and commend it to the House. the shadow minister, the honourable member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey) and hope that, sensible as it is, it will be acceptable to the government. It is entirely consistent with the main thrust of the legislation and therefore should not be objectionable. A number of matters in the legislation are commendable and seem to be raising no objections from the veterans community. The only overall objection-that I assume the honourable member has referred to in his speech, which I, unfortunately, was not here for-is that the legislation has been brought in too quickly. I hesitate to suggest that it is being rushed through because there is no apparent reason to rush it through for the sake of hiding anything. In the end, the benefits for veterans ought to be in place as soon as possible and, after all, the legislation implements some of the budget decisions. The shadow minister would have made it clear that we may see fit to move some further amendments in the Senate in due course. It is intended that compensation recovery payments such as accident, sickness and workers compensation payments received by service pensioners and income support supplement recipients be aligned with the way in which compensation payments received by recipients of comparable social security payments are treated under the Social Security Act. This matter raises some general concerns about the treatment of veterans. I have not heard the Minister for Veterans' Affairs( Mr Sciacca) speak about this particular case but I have heard him argue on other occasions for this sort of treatment. In my view, this raises the spectre of a constant attempt to break down the special status of veterans as a distinct group of people. Whilst in this case it may be unobjectionable, and there may well be some arguments for doing it, I make the general statement that this is a concern and that it has happened consistently. I argued against it most recently when the government brought in legislation, not so long ago, to bring the treatment of shares that were owned by pensioners into line with the treatment of shares that were owned by social security beneficiaries. I make the point again that over time we are increasingly seeing this alignment. There is a concern in the veterans community, which the minister will be aware of, because I know that it is widely expressed, that over time the status of veterans will be diminished. There will come a time-and it may well be that the time when it does come will be the right timewhen veterans' entitlements may be totally consumed into the wider social security network. I am not by any means advocating that this should occur, although, realistically, some decades down the track the movement to do that will gather momentum. But in the meantime there is a very strong view among those in the veterans community that their affairs ought to be separate; that their benefits are always to be seen as compensation, not welfare; and that therefore the attempt, at every opportunity, to align veterans benefits with social security benefits per se is a concern, even though it may be supported by equity, or by some other arguments. I make this point because whenever veterans affairs are debated in this parliament, I make a plea for those in the veterans community that their entitlements and benefits be seen in that very special light, and that their special status in the community be safeguarded, and in no way downgraded. I only do that because there are widely held suspicions, despite the current
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Bradford (Mcpherson) (10.48 A.m.)
theText: I support the amendment foreshadowed byThursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2575 minister's obvious commitment to his role. Perhaps veterans become a little irrational about their concerns-but they do so with some justification, because over the years there have been furphies about scrapping the Department of Veterans' Affairs and about lots of other things that would be of great concern to veterans. The commitment to maintain a ministry of veterans' affairs is very important. In practice, that means that ultimately there is a very high level of commitment by governments of both persuasions to veterans' affairs, by the maintenance of that distinct department. It will be a sad day-and, as I say, it will probably come many years down the track-when there will not be the definite need for a separate department, but there is a need at present, and there will be for a long period of time to come. In particular, in relation to compensation recovery, there were a couple of questions that the minister might address. The answers may be evident, but I am not aware of them. I assume that when compensation recovery happens, any compensation payments received subsequently would be affected by the new mechanism. I am not sure whether there is any retrospective element to this. If people have received compensation payments in the past and they are receiving benefits, I would assume that arrangement is not affected at all, but maybe that is part of the alignment. Perhaps the answer to that question lies in the way that those sorts of awards are treated by the Department of Social Security. The question about the actual timing of all of this obviously would be of concern to veterans and I think needs to be answered. I did receive, and I draw it to the minister's attention, a magazine article headed 'A thorny problem attacked: section 74 Veteran's Entitlements Act'. It reads: Since 1972 the Regular Serviceman has had the right to claim benefits under both the Commonwealth's compensation legislation and the Veteran's Entitlements legislation for the same service caused impairment/disability or incapacity to work. How this curious state of affairs came about is another subject. Where a serviceman has exercised rights and received benefits under both pieces of legislation for the same injury. one or the other benefit must be repaid. Section 74 VE Act provides the mechanism and it does not do a brilliant job. This raises the spectre of how confusing a lot of these entitlements and the interpretation of these entitlements have become. In all of these schemes, not only those for veterans and social security, it is instructive to hear the Minister for Social Security( Mr Baldwin) in the parliament trying to explain some of the government's so-called initiatives and to deal with the anomalies and the unintended consequences. I will not get too side-tracked, but the general principle is that everything seems so complicated. This article goes on to say: The compensatory principles differ. Commonwealth Compensation compensates by periodic (fortnightly) payments for incapacity to work, or by lump sum award for impairment/disablement. or both. Veterans' Entitlements compensates by DVA pension (fortnightly) which is generally for impairment/disability up to 100 per cent General Rate and incapacity to work at Intermediate and Special (TPI) rates. The number of combinations that can arise are many and complicated. The article outlined one situation: The serviceman was granted a DVA pension in 1982 and then in 1984 he was awarded lump sum compensation. Section 74(3) 'deemed' that the 1984 lump sum award was to be treated as if it were paid in fortnightly payments over the actuarial life (life expectancy) of the man as determined by the Australian Government Actuary. The 1984 award was also 'deemed' to have been paid to him in 1982 when the grant of DVA pension was made. The man's actuarial life was calculated on his age in 1982 giving his life expectancy to the year 2003 inclusive. 2576 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 In the result, the lump sum award was spread out as fortnightly 'deemed' payments from 1982 to 2003 inclusive and deducted from his pension payments. When the lump sum was awarded in 1984 the sum of the 'deemed' payments from 1982 pension date to 1984 award date was deducted from the award. The balance of the award or the 'over-payment' was paid over to the man with the intention of being recovered by deduction of the 'deemed' payments from future fortnightly pension. On a doJlar-for-doJlar basis though complicated this sounds fair enough but, it was not on such basis. Section 74(3) said more. The Actuary also had to make the sum of all the 'deemed' payments equivalent to (not equal to) the 1984 award 'deemed' made in 1982. This required the Actuary to employ present value principles and the problem gets sticky. That just illustrates the complications which are faced by people. I assume that that sort of scenario is something that is being addressed in part by this legislation. But all of this deeming that we went through and all the problems that it created, all the unintended consequences, really make life difficult for veterans and their spouses. I make that point because I feel strongly that their lives ought to be uncomplicated, particularly those of the older veterans. By and large, younger veterans are still able to take care of themselves, but many of the older veterans cannot. They come to see me. They sit in front of me-and some of them are in their 80s-and they tell me how they are being harassed, or how they have concerns. Some of those concerns are rational, some perhaps are not so rational. However, my heart goes out to them every time. It is easy for me to say, 'The government or the department or whatever should leave you alone to get on with your life.' Their life expectancy is not very long when we are talking about veterans of the Second World War or even the Korean war. They are getting old. They ought not be harassed. They ought not have their lives made difficult. Sometimes a cost is involved in making those decisions. I do not want to get into an argument about whether the mechanisms are reasonable or not. The point is, once veterans have reached a certain age, it is unrealistic and unreasonable to fight them to the nth degree and to complicate their lives. I assume that that will be the result of this. The existing situation that I have just outlined is complicated enough. It will continue to be so, and yet I do not believe it should be. The government spends heaps of money on all sorts of things. Every day in the parliament we hear members of the government talking about a million dollars for this and a few million dollars for that. gets up to answer a question, millions of dollars are mentioned-$2 million for this, $1 million or whatever. However, when it comes to a poor veteran fighting over next to nothing, it seems to be the biggest deal of all time. The government goes to all sorts of lengths to make sure everything is deemed. It makes lots of calculations to make sure that the veteran does not get one cent more than he is entitled to. I just throw my hands up in the air, and in the end I come down on the side of, in particular, the older veterans. At some point in time they should be given everything they are entitled to-using that term fairly loosely. We should be saving money in the areas of government waste, extravagance and vote buying exercises. We see them every day of the week in the parliament, and yet the government wants to be hard on veterans. It does not make sense. The point was raised about expenses incurred by applicants to the VRB. Although the cost of medical evidence is reimbursed, under the provisions of the VEA and at the AAT those costs can be met through legal aid grants. I am sure the minister is aware-and I do not know

When it comes to the question of veterans, in a bipartisan way, we are always prepared to acknowledge that they are a special group of people and, as such, they should be treated specially. At the end of the day, there are specific measures in this bill-for instance, the compensation measure, which was mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for McPherson( Mr Bradford)-that are not retrospective; the bill comes into effect from 1 January 1995. The other chamber needs to have these measures before it in order to consider them by a certain time. This lack of time was more to do with those procedures than with any intention on my part not to give my friend the chance to have a look at it. I certainly say to the honourable member for O'Connor that, if there is a way of giving him more time with the legislation, I would be more than happy to do that. In future, we will try to give him extra time. It was not an intended constraint. This bill is part of a package of measures that we announced in the budget. This did not go through in the first budget measures bill simply because we were not able to get everything up and ready in time. These provisions are mostly beneficial provisions and they were part of a package which was absolutely and exhaustively gone through with the ex-service communities. The honourable member for O'Connor also talked about the automatic payment of the funeral benefits. At the moment, the class of person covered has to apply for that funeral benefit. Such people will no longer have to apply; we will pay it automatically. There are administrative procedures in place. For instance, the ex-service community always looks at the death notices and these sorts of things. The ex-service community is very good when it comes to this. In most cases, particularly if people are receiving an extreme disabled adjustment and if they are in the other class as well, the ex-prisoner of war class, everyone knows who they are and someone is on to us very quickly. speaker: Mr Sciacca (Bowman
theText: Minister for Veterans' Affairs) (11.05 a.m.)-in reply-I thank2578 MAIN COMMI'ITEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 people are chased until we are finally notified. I take the point that the honourable member makes and I understand what he is saying. With respect to appeals, I am concerned that there are too many appeals which, at the end, are granted anyway. One of the major reasons that we brought this in as part of the package of measures was to make sure that we get people to bring their medical evidence not only at Veterans Review Board level but also at the primary level. The way it works now is that those who go to the primary level usually do not think they have got a chance anyway so they tum up without appropriate information. They then go to the Veterans Review Board and do the same thing because, if they win, they get something for their medical reports-and we all know medical reports can be very expensive. If they lose, they get nothing. Normally, they keep the powder dry, so to speak, until they go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, where a veteran can get automatic legal aid for these matters. They wait for that. What happens? My colleagues the lawyers make plenty of money out of it. Frankly, I would prefer to spend that money that my department is spending at the AAT on the veterans themselves rather than on lawyers, and I say that as a lawyer myself. We now say that, whenever veterans go to the Veterans Review Board, we will give them up to $425 for each medical report on a separate condition. I believe that will mean that the advocates will come forward with that report. Hopefully, if it is going to be accepted, it is accepted there and then. It cuts out delays; it cuts out costs. Probably delay is the major thing. At the end of the day, if a veteran wins, he or she wins and gets paid from the date of making the application. I want to say a few things about the Specialist Medical Review Council and the amendment that has been proposed by the honourable member for O'Connor. As far as today is concerned, I am ruling it out; I am not prepared to accept it and I will tell him why. I have very good reasons for that. The point is that the Specialist Medical Review Council will not be hearing individual cases. I do not expect that there will be that many appeals to the Specialist Medical Review Council. When I discussed this quite cooperatively with the shadow spokesman I took into consideration the fact that this would not happen often. Nevertheless, I was happy to acknowledge that that could be the case, that there would be certain times when there would be medical conditions when the Repatriation Medical Authority would say, 'No, we are not prepared to put it into a statement of principle'. Therefore, we would give the opportunity to an individual or an ex-service organisation to go to the Specialist Medical Review Council. But that basically is a medical thing. The council is not going to handle individual cases; it is looking at causations, it is looking at medical principlesthey would have to get will be different from what this sort of payment is being introduced for. The rationale behind this payment is to make sure that we cut down delays to veterans, to make sure that they come with all the appropriate information to the Veterans Review Board so that we can cut down delays and cut down costs. I would envisage that for those who do appeal to the Specialist Medical Review Counciland I would expect that that would be a very limited number of cases-it would be more of a doctor and doctor sort of thing. For instance, an ex-service organisation might take up the case on behalf of a veteran. I would see that that would be the way it would work. Someone

theText: They have to get medical advice though.

speaker: Mr Sciacca
theText: Yes, they have to get medical advice but the sort of medical advice thatThursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2579 would take up the case because it is really a class of people that is appealing against a particular medical principle. I would expect that that sort of case would be such that paying $425 for a medical report would neither be here nor there in the sense that it really would not be of any great assistance. This $425 is specifically meant to help the individual veteran who has to be able to prove that he has a case, that he has a particular disease. It will not really matter as long as the statement of principle says, for instance, that smoking causes lung cancer. All that individual has to prove is that, firstly, he has got lung cancer and, secondly, that he has smoked. He has got to get a doctor to say that in his opinion he has got lung cancer because he smoked. It is not that the doctor's report wiIl be in terms of a statement of principle referring it back to that; it is connecting the disease or the injury to the particular principle. I understand the good intentions of the honourable member for O'Connor in suggesting this but I just do not believe that it is anything that is going to be of any real benefit and perhaps we might leave this to the Senate later on to discuss. I certainly will not accept it now, not because I am against the principle of it but because I just do not think it is necessary. I want to make another point which I think is very important. The honourable member for O'Connor mentioned that we should thank members of the opposition because of the fact that they asked us to agree to a Specialist Medical Review Council in the event that there were statements of principles that come out of the Medical Review Authority which we did not agree on. I think, if I remember correctly, that he put out a press release shortly after I made the announcement on the Agent Orange extension range of cancers. I thought about it. I was tempted to whip one out and say, 'Wrong, Mr Tuckey', but I said, 'No'. I considered that the honourable member for O'Connor and I have been getting on well when it comes to cooperating on these bills and so I decided that I do not particularly want to stick it into him. But I want to tell him now, given that he mentioned it-I was not going to mention it-that one of the major reasons why I baulked originally about the setting up of the Specialist Medical Review Council was that there already is in the act-it was part of my bill-a section that there would always be that residual power of the Repatriation Commission to overrule any statement of principle of the Repatriation Medical Authority provided that that overruling procedure would be in favour of the veteran. In this case, the Repatriation Commission has referred to the Repatriation Medical Authority, for the compiling of statement of principles, these extensions of the five new cancers that we are now going to accept as a result of the reports from Professors MacLennan and Smith. In the event, that the Repatriation Medical Authority says, 'No, we do not agree'-and I think that is quite unlikely but it is a possibility-we do not have to wait. I have already made the commitment on behalf of the government that we are going to do this quickly. There is no way in the world that we are going to wait until someone arranges to appeal this to the Specialist Medical Review Council. It will go straight back to the Repatriation Commission. It was the one that had accepted that extension and referred it to the RMA. It has the power immediately to say, 'In this case, because it is such an important groundbreaking issue, as far as we are concerned it is in favour of the veteran. We have the power to do that.' I think it is in section 108A of the act-or certainly of the last bill that I brought in which set up the Repatriation Medical Authority. The point I am making to my honourable friend is that it is already there. I hope he has more regard for my ability than to think I was going to get up and make a public statement 2580 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 knowing full well that there was some chance that I was going to get knocked back by the Repatriation Medical Authority. I can assure him that that will not be the case. I did not want to make an issue of it. I thought it was a bit complicated. I said, 'We are getting on well with these matters' and I said, 'I do not think we will do that'. I appreciate that we are at one when it comes to looking after the general interests of the veterans. It is my belief that I should do the best I can. It is his belief that he should be the advocate. I accept that. I think that is the proper role when dealing with a portfolio like this. There is no politics in veterans affairs. They deserve, I think, a bit better than that. The honourable member mentioned a particular PTSD case. I thank him for referring that case to me. I have the details in my pocket and I will certainly take it up. I appreciate his doing that. That is an area which I am very interested in. It is an area in which we are spending a lot of money. Only recently, I officially opened a PTSD specialist centre at Heidelberg Hospital under the directorship of Professor Philip Morris. We are getting treatment protocols from the United States and other places. We are getting as much information as we can. PTSD is real. It is something which cannot be cured. It can only be treated. What we are trying to do is organise treatment protocols. We are going to diffuse those throughout the states through the St John of God Hospital in New South Wales and through our veterans advice networks and Vietnam veterans counselling services. The honourable member for O'Connor mentioned how Vietnam veterans in particular have this problem and end up with all sorts of social problems as a result. That is something which we are not only going to look at, but do something about. It took a long time for the Australian public to realise the specific problems suffered by people involved in that conflict. I did a television interview yesterday in which it was suggested to me that perhaps the government was being generous in extending the benefits in terms of Agent Orange to five new sets of cancers. This particular interviewer suggested that in real terms there is no conclusive link between exposure to herbicides and certain cancers. I said to him, 'Look, the report that I received from Professors MacLennan and Smith said that in their opinion there was, but that in any event the government should give them the benefit of the doubt. In the context of the generous nature of the repatriation system in this country' -and it is one of the best in the world, and there are a lot of people trying to get on board from allied countries who cannot-Owe have given them the benefit of the doubt.' I continued, 'If you think about it, we sent 50,000 people over to that conflict. When they returned, the majority of the people over here were against the war' -and I was one of them, and I have said as much publicly-'and they were brought back in the middle of the night. They were asked to take off their uniforms and to go out through the crowds in pairs, dressed in civvies, so that they were not regardedveterans. It probably did not happen to you, and I accept that but I did say 'in some cases'. That sort of thing is something which would have taken them a long time to forget. I told the interviewer that if at the end of the day we could do something to ease their minds and let them know that we were thinking of them, so be it; I was prepared to give them the benefit of the doubt. I do not think honourable members would disagree with that action that we took.

theText: In some cases, evidently, it was true. I have been told this by VietnamThursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITfEE 2581 The honourable member for McPherson mentioned the hassles that older veterans have, and I accept that. I also assure the honourable member for McPherson that there is certainly no thought by this government of getting rid of, or in any way dissolving, the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is quite the contrary. In fact, everything we are doing is the other way around. We are taking away from Social Security the war widow income supplement; DVA is going to pay it as of and from 30 March next year. The single rate of pension to service pension widows will now come over to our department whereas, in the past, if they stayed with our department they got only half the married rate. All these sorts of things are being looked at. The other day I set up a task force with the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to look at the aged care needs of veterans. That certainly is not indicative of wanting to get rid of Veterans' Affairs or a diminishing of veterans' entitlements. I appreciate the points that have been put forward, and I accept them in the spirit in which they were intended. Whenever there are good suggestions from the opposition or from anyone I will always take them up. I commend the bill to the House. I will keep an open mind in terms of the Senate, but I am inclined to say at this stage that there is no necessity for the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for O'Connor and that I am not prepared to accept it. Bill agreed to without amendment. the House without amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative. Consideration resumed from 13 October. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. This small portfolio bill contains three amendments to Veterans' Affairs benefits. Its major purpose is to increase the age at which female veterans can qualify for age service pension. The bill also contains two other minor measures-an increase in the maximum rate of the dependent child add-on which is payable to service pensioners for children under the age of 16 years, and the reintroduction of advance pharmaceutical allowance. The decision to increase the qualifying age for women receiving age pension from the Department of Social Security and age service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs was part of the government's 1993 Budget. Legislation giving effect to this proposal for Social Security age pensions has already been passed. The increase in the qualifying age will be slowly phased in with the first adjustment occurring on 1 July 1995. This bill proposes that from 1 July 1995 the qualifying age for age service pension for female veterans will be 55 1h years. Thereafter, the qualifying age will increase by six months every two years. It will not be until the year 2014 that the age service pension age for women will be 60 years. The qualifying age for women will then be the same as the existing qualifying age for men. The second initiative is also part of the 1993 Budget. The maximum rate of additional family payment paid by Social Security was increased by $1 per week for each child under 16 years of age. This decision was part of a package to assist low income earners and unemployed persons to offset increases in the wholesale tax announced in that year.

speaker: Mr Les Scott
theText: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is certainly a learning experience.2590 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 Affairs' Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) of 1994. This bill will bring the veterans pensions into line with the aged pension by increasing the qualifying age at which women can apply for the aged service pension from 55 to 65 years, over a lO-year period. The bill will also reintroduce the advance pharmaceutical allowance from January next year. This is a measure that is welcome. Thirdly, the bill will increase the maximum rate of the dependent child add-on by $52 a year for service pensioners with children under 16 years of age. This change to the pension entitlements for women is a reflection of the change that was included in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act (No.2) of 1994. The reason for this is simple. The original distinction between the pension ages for men and women was based on the fact that, in the past, there was a much lower labour force participation rate for women. I stand here today, as a particularly happy and proud woman, to say that this is one of the areas where women are definitely making inroads. The statistics bear those inroads out. It is because of that increased participation rate in the work force for women that the pension age for women will slowly be increased from the current level of 55 years to 60 years. The first increment will take place on 1 July 1995. The phasing in will be entirely equitable, and will take place over an extended period of time. This method of implementation recognises the remaining labour force disadvantages incurred over the years by the older women affected by these measures. I must stress, however, that the great bulk of female veterans will not be affected by these measures, because they are already older than 63 and in receipt of the service pension. The small number of women who would have qualified at 55, and who now, under this new system, will not, will have access to labour force programs and supporting measures like the jobsearch allowance. We are not leaving them behind at any time. Women veterans who have a permanent incapacity which prevents them from working will continue to have access to the invalid service pension at any age. As I have already stated, these changes will be implemented over a long period of time. Every two years the pension age for women will increase by six months. Increments will occur progressively on this basis until 1 January 2014. At this time, the pensionable age will be 60 years. A woman will attain pensionable age only once. Once a woman attains the age where she can claim a pension, she is eligible for that pension from then on. This is the case even if she does not claim the pension at that particular time. The reason for this is that, under the strictest possible application of the formula for the pension, it is possible for a woman to obtain pensionable age and then lose it. This bill makes sure that once pensionable age is attained it is maintained. The second major provision of this bill is the reintroduction of provisions for the payment of the advance pharmaceutical allowance, which will take effect from 1 January 1995. From1 November 1990, provision was made for chronically ill pensioners who constantly used a high volume of drugs to have access to the advance pharmaceutical allowance. This was initially introduced for a period of one year, and was later extended for a further two years. These provisions were later removed. The bill we have before us today will reintroduce access to that facility. With the passage of this bill, from 1 January 1995 the advance pharmaceutical allowance will again be paid. As well as the fact that this facility will be reintroduced, it will also no longer be subject to sunset provisions. The ability to gain payment of the advance pharmaceutical allowance is back, and it is here to stay.
