We should never forget the veterans. I commend the bill to the House. Ms DEAHM (Macquarie) (12.08 p.m.)-It is always a privilege to speak on a veterans' affairs bill. I think I have spoken on most of them since I have been in this place because, as the honourable member for Bass( Mrs Silvia Smith) has already said, veterans are very important people in our life. I think, when we talk about veterans' affairs, that we need to take an historical perspective on Australia's involvement in war. Australia is a small nation and, even before it became a nation, its people were sending troops to war. From the Sudan through to Vietnam we have sent our troops to wars, mostly wars that were not our own. I would make an exception with that part of the Second World War when the Japanese came into the war and our country was definitely under threat. So, for the most part, we have been generous in war. We have given our troops, our services, to other nations. Of course, in the beginning we were part of what was then known as the 'mother country' and we are a part of the Commonwealth. I am sure all honourable members will, if they did not see it in person, certainly have seen replayed many times the then Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, saying that, as a consequence of Britain being at war, Australia was also at war. In lots of cases we had no choice and we sent our personnel, mostly our men, to those wars. Ninety-four thousand men-mostly men-have died in those wars, starting with the Sudan, the Boxer rebellion and the Boer War. They were wars that are mostly forgotten now except for the two world wars, Korea and Vietnam. We have made an enormous sacrifice, one that is totally out of proportion to our population and to our strategic position in the world. We also need to be aware of the profound effects that war has had, not only on those who took part in those encounters but on their families, and here I speak very much from personal experience. My father was in the navy practically all his working life so, as a child, I was used to his being away. Of course, during the war he was away virtually all the time so I never saw him very much then. I did not really get to know him until I was in my teens, and shortly after that he died. He died at the age of 58 from a heart disease but it was considered to have been due to war service. He was a TPI. So the toll on the families has been enormous and it is something we often forget. There was a TV program recently about women in war and it showed families where the children were scared of their fathers. I have to say that I was one of those. I was to rejoice when my father came home and all I knew was that this man in a uniform came in and within five minutes had me in tears because he was trying to run the family as he thought it ought to be run. It was not his fault, it was not my mother's fault, it was the fault of the fact that he was at war. After the war he spent a considerable time in New Guinea and northern Australia on minesweepers, so once again he was absent. I think that profound effect on the families is something we ought to remember. For that reason the measures that we have brought in for veterans and for their families are very worthwhile, and an organisation like Legacy does a tremendous job in working with those people. Several of the previous speakers have talked about the heroes of war, people from their own electorates. I made a speech in this place some time ago about two particular men I met last ANZAC Day, Dr Jim Thorp and Mr John Robinson. They were both in their 90s and both had served in both world wars. Dr ThorpI alluded to in particular because unfortunately he died shortly after I met him on ANZAC Day. He was 98 or 99 at that stage. He had gone to the First 2594 MAIN COMMIITEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 World War as a medical orderly. During the interim he trained as a doctor and he went back as a medical officer. Those people have made an enormous contribution and they are deserving of everything we can give them. The member for Bass alluded to the kinds of things that Australia does for its veterans compared with other countries. I was very much aware as a child of men coming back from war and receiving an opportunity to study; their fees were paid if they wanted to undertake a course of study. They were given grants of land if they wanted to start a smallholding or a farm and also were given assistance with their house payments to buy a house. When my father died, my mother then took over the war service home loan, which was at a very low rate. I think we have done and we continue to do a lot for our veterans, particularly in the area of health, and also in counselling. That is something that is fairly new. Unfortunately, there are still some people in the ADF who think that counselling is a bit wussy and something that only soft people need. The traumas of war, I think, are something we have overlooked for too long. In the First World War people were shot for deserting, for cowardice, and really they were suffering from what we now know as stress syndrome. Fortunately we have now recognised this with our Vietnam veterans, who had a doubly bad time because not only did they suffer from all those things that they saw and were engaged in but also they suffered to a great extent from rejection by a lot of people in their own community. I have spoken of this before but I am very proud that there is a post-traumatic stress syndrome program at the St John of God Hospital in Richmond in my electorate which is going extremely well. Only last week it received an award from the Private Hospitals Association of New South Wales, and I will be writing to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs( Mr Sciacca) about that shortly. I hope he will write a letter congratulating the hospital on that success. I was fortunate to go and talk to some of the men who were engaged in its first program and they told me about some of the trauma they were going through in that program just recalling things that had happened to them and feeling as though they wanted to run away and get out of there. However, their comrades-they did not know each other before they went in but they were soon comrades because they had been in the same engagement-helped by saying, 'No, hang in. It is going to be worthwhile.' NowI am getting feedback from those people saying what a benefit it was. One particular case which I cannot resist mentioning, and I have sent a letter to the minister about this, was mentioned in a letter from one of the participants in that program who lives on the north coast of New South Wales. He wrote to the hospital and said that one of his fellow participants had come to see him recently for a cup of coffee. Not very sensational. But it was sensational because that man had driven from Sydney to the north coast and that is the first time he had been out on his own, virtually since he had left Vietnam, except to go to and from hospital. That was a big thing for him to get over that phobia, get in the car and drive and then sit down to talk with a mate. Of course, Britain was not in a position to be as generous as Australia was, because we had our own natural wealth on which to call; whereas Britain, of course, was devastated during the war, so her people did not do as well. BILL 1994 Consideration resumed from 19 September. Second Reading That the bill be now read a second time. The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SI(S) Act) and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993. Those acts formed the centrepiece of a package of superannuation legislation which received royal assent on 30 November 1993 and which gave effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation that the Treasurer announced on 21 October 1992. This bill makes a number of amendments, many of a technical nature, to the above mentioned acts aimed at further enhancing and refining the operation of those acts. I tum to the main provisions outlined in these amendments. Allowing certain non-bank financial institutions to otTer 'approved guarantees' The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow certain non-bank financial institutions to offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. Currently, only approved banks and the Commonwealth, states or territories can offer the guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. Building societies, credit unions and similar organisations which are subject to supervision under the various state financial institutions codes are considered to be institutions which should also be able to offer the guarantees required under the SI(S) Act and this bill amends the SI(S) Act accordingly.

speaker: Mr Elliott (Parramatta
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer) (12.25 p.m.)-I move:2598 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 Allowing 'in-house' investments in certain non-bank financial institutions An 'in-house asset' is essentially a loan to, or investment in, a standard employer sponsor of the fund-or an associate of such an employer sponsor-and the SI(S) Act places restrictions, for prudential reasons, on the level of such investments. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to treat deposits in certain non-bank financial institutionswhich are subject to prudential supervision-in the same manner as deposits in an approved bank with regard to determining if they are 'in-house assets'. Applications for the issue of a superannuation interest and application to become a standard employer-sponsor The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that the trustee cannot accept a person as a member of a public offer entity unless that person has applied in the appropriate manner and has received relevant information-determined by the Commissioner-regarding the entity before doing so. Acquisition of certain assets from members of regulated superannuation funds The SI(S) Act imposes a general prohibition on the acquisition of assets from members, subject to a limited exception in relation to funds with less than five members-excluded superannuation funds-provided the asset acquired is business real property. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that an excluded superannuation fund can only acquire business real property from a member-or relative of a member-if the property is business real property in the member's-or relative's-principal business. This ensures that the right balance is struck between allowing the acquisition of business real property from members of excluded funds and recognising the dangers-from a prudential, retirement incomes and taxation revenue perspective-in such an approach. Public otTer superannuation funds and equal representation The SI(S) Act currently requires a standard employer sponsored fund which is a public offer fund to have an independent trustee. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow such funds the option of either having an independent trustee or having equal numbers of employer and member representatives involved in the trusteeship of the fund. This provides funds with greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship while at the same time ensuring that members are protected-in the first instance by having a trustee who is independent and in the second by having direct involvement in the fund via equal representation. Existing trustee may give notice of retirement A fundamental principle of the SI(S) Act is that superannuation entities should be in the control of a single party-the trustees-who take full responsibility for the fund. However, the Corporations Law currently requires that superannuation entities which are public offer entities have dual responsible parties-the trustee and the management company. The SI(S) Act enables these public offer entities to change to have a single party in control of the fund. In many cases this will involve the trustee retiring and the management company taking over the role of trustee. The effective and smooth operation of this changeover may be hampered if the existing trustee is required to hold a meeting of beneficiaries before retiring-as the governing rules of some superannuation entities may require. To overcome this problem, and therefore to Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 2599 ensure a smooth changeover, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to provide that such a requirement in the governing rules of a fund has no effect. Secrecy provisions The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow the minister to approve disclosure of protected information-if it is in the public interest to do so-to the public at large, rather than just to particular members of the public. At the same time the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that appropriate protection is provided to an individual by only allowing disclosure of information that relates to the private affairs of an individual where such disclosure would not be unreasonable in the circumstances. Allowing the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow officers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC, to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Protected information is information relating to the affairs of a fund which the ISC has obtained in the course of carrying out its supervisory duties. While the ISC is allowed to provide such information to bodies such as the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Taxation Office there is no allowance to provide such information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The Superannuation Complaints Tribunal commenced operation on 1 July 1994 and provides a quick and fair mechanism, which previously did not exist, for dealing with member complaints regarding superannuation. The restriction on the provision of protected information, where that information is directly relevant to a particular complaint, is hampering the effective operation of the complaints tribunal. The amendment allows the ISC to provide such relevant information to the complaints tribunal. Approved purposes of, and payments to beneficiaries in, an approved deposit fund The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure consistency between related provisions in the act which deal with the purposes for which an approved deposit fund may be maintained and payments to beneficiaries. This clarifies the existing obligations. Disqualified persons not to be custodians The SI(S) Act currently restricts disqualified persons from being trustees or investment managers of superannuation entities. There is however no similar requirement on custodians. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to address this problem and ensure that custodians are subject to similar 'eligibility' requirements to those applying to trustees and investment managers. Removal of trustees of public otTer entities The bill inserts a new requirement into the SI(S) Act to prevent another party from trying to exert undue influence on a trustee by threatening to remove the trustee unless the trustee complies with that party's requests. The amendment ensures that no other party would have the power to exercise such influence by ensuring that, unless the regulations provide otherwise, no person, other than the Commissioner, can remove a trustee of a public offer entity. Allowing exempt public sector superannuation schemes to become subject to the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993 The bill amends the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, termed the SRC Act, to allow exempt public sector superannuation schemes to become subject to the act. 2600 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 Currently only regulated superannuation funds, and approved deposit funds, are subject to the SRC Act and thus only members of those funds can make use of the superannuation complaints tribunal. Many public sector superannuation schemes will not be regulated funds. Instead they will be exempt public sector superannuation schemes and members of such schemes will not therefore be able to use the complaints tribunal. In some cases this is acceptable as there are other appropriate complaints mechanisms available for members of such schemes. However some schemes believe their members should have and need access to the complaints tribunal. The amendment enables such schemes to become subject to the SRC Act and so have such access to the tribunal. Other provisions More detailed information on the amendments made by this bill and an explanation of those amendments is contained in the explanatory memorandum. The amendments made by this bill have no revenue implications. I commend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 to the House. referring to procedures which have been adopted at the same time as, but not in any way related to, the establishment of this committee. This bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, was introduced into the House on 19 September after passing through the Senate on 30 August. It sets out to amend the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act 1993, known as the SI(S) Act, and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, or the SRC Act. The SI(S) Act effectively began operating on 1 July of this year. The principal act provides the legislative framework for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds, particularly the security of members' moneys, and for certain minimum standards. The

theText: In the context of this debate I want to open byThursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2601 principal act has already been amended once this year by the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. Amendments to the SI(S) Act and to the SRC Act currently before us are aimed at enhancing the operations of those acts. The coalition does not oppose this bill because the amendments represent primarily housekeeping measures. As the parliamentary secretary has already pointed out, there is no financial impact arising from these measures. The amendment bill before us is largely the result of the willingness of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the ISC, to listen to the concerns and recommendations of the superannuation industry. The performance of the ISC can be largely measured by the degree to which the industry can work with it. Also, according to Senator Watson, who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, the ISC has developed a good working relationship with the select committee and with his office. The ISC should be commended on its performance to date and I sincerely hope that other agencies, such as the Australian Taxation Office, can take its example and be less confrontational. One matter that relates to the operation of the ISC and the need for amendment bills is that under part 29 of the SI(S) Act the ISC has the power to modify provisions of the act, either temporarily or permanently. Modifications of a permanent nature are of concern. They effectively have the potential to change the intention of the act. Of course, modification orders are gazetted, but they are not subject to the scrutiny that amendment bills or regulations would receive in the normal course of events. Parliament, by allowing modifications, is delegating its legislative role to a government agency in circumstances where there is no form of legislated requirement for review. To the best of my knowledge, to date the ISC has used its power to modify the SI(S) Act in a responsible manner, so I am anticipating a concern. I believe this is an issue to which members of the House should give consideration. Should we be prepared to delegate our legislative role in this way or should we take a more active position in protecting the legislative workings of the parliament? That is the question I want honourable members to consider. It would be preferable for permanent modifications to the SI(S) Act to be achieved by legislative change, with the ISC modifications being used only as a temporary measure. A majority of the amendments made by this bill affect the SI(S) Act. The bill, as it was originally introduced into the Senate, has already been amended. Many of the amendments are of a minor and technical nature. WhereI mention in the course of my remarks the relevant division of the bill, it should be assumed that I am referring to those divisions in part 2 that are amendments to the SI(S) Act, unless I indicate otherwise. Division3 allows certain non-bank financial institutions to offer what are known as approved guarantees. This measure relates to the standard of investments. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow certain non-bank financial institutions to offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. Currently, only approved banks, and the Commonwealth, states or territories, can offer guarantees required under the SI(S) Act. The bill also amends the SI(S) Act to enable building societies, credit unions and similar organisations, which are subject to supervision under the various state financial institutions codes, to also be able to offer such guarantees. As well, division 3 allows 'in-house' investments in certain non-bank financial institutions. 2602 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 An 'in-house asset' is essentially a loan to, or an investment in, a standard employer sponsor of the fund, or an associate of such an employer sponsor, and the SI(S) Act places restrictions, for prudential reasons, on the level of such investments. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to treat deposits in certain non-bank financial institutions, which are subject to prudential supervision, in the same manner as deposits in an approved bank, with the objective of determining whether they are in-house assets. The effect of this amendment is significant, as the SI(S) Act restricts the in-house assets of regulated superannuation funds to 10 per cent of the total assets in most cases. What it does is rope in the non-bank institutions, such as building societies and the like. Division7 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that a trustee cannot accept a person as a member of a public offer entity, unless that person has applied in the appropriate manner and has received relevant information, of a calibre determined by the commissioner, about the entity beforehand. Division 11 amends section 66 of the SI(S) Act. The SI(S) Act imposes a general prohibition on the acquisition of assets from members, subject to a limited exception for funds with less than five members, known as excluded superannuation funds, provided the asset acquired is business real property. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that an excluded superannuation fund can only acquire business real property from a member, or relative of a member, if the property is business real property in the member's or relative's principal business. The SI(S) Act currently requires a standard employer sponsored fund, which is a public offer fund, to have an independent trustee. Division 12 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow such funds the option of either having an independent trustee, or having equal numbers of employer and member representatives, involved in the trusteeship of the fund. This provides funds with greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship, while at the same time ensuring that members are protected in the first instance by having a trustee who is independent, and, in the second, by having direct involvement in the fund via equal representation. Employee representatives need not necessarily be members of the superannuation fund. They are usually representatives nominated by the members of a fund, a trade union or other organisation representing the interests of those members. There is much merit in having employee trustees. Even where the option of an independent trustee is taken up, it would be useful if funds were required to have at least one representative from the fund membership who is, in the vernacular, from the shop floor. Such a fund member representative would benefit the prudential protection of the fund and reassure workers that the fund is sound. It is a matter I believe the ISC should give serious consideration to. It is also a matter that Senator Watson has been pursuing for some time with no response from the government so far. Overall, this amendment to sections 91 to 93 of the SI(S) Act will undoubtedly provide funds with much greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship. It will also ensure that members are protected by having a trustee who is independent and by having direct involvement in the fund by means of equal representation. Division 13 allows for existing trustees to give a notice of retirement without a need to call a meeting of beneficiaries. A fundamental principle of the SI(S) Act is that superannuation entities should be in control of a single party-the trustees who take full responsibility for the fund. However, corporations law currently requires that superannuation entities which are public offer entities have dually responsible parties comprising the trustees and the Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2603 management company. The SI(S) Act enables these public offer entities to change to a single party in control of the fund. In many cases this will involve the trustee retiring and the management company taking over the role of trustee. The effective and smooth operation of this changeover may be hampered if the existing trustee is required to hold a meeting of beneficiaries before retiring, as the governing rules of some superannuation entities may in fact require. To overcome that problem and therefore to ensure a smoother changeover, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to provide that such a requirement in the governing rules of the fund will have no effect. This is a common sense measure. It will eliminate the unnecessary expense to superannuation funds where an existing trustee retires as a result of provisions in the SI(S) Act. Division 14 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow the minister to approve disclosure of otherwise protected information, if it is in the public interest to do so, to the public at large rather than to particular members of the public. How the public interest is defined is always interesting. I have no doubt it will be the same in this case. Naturally enough, the public interest as perceived by the minister could be very different from that of an impartial observer. Where such disclosure does occur, I hope it is only undertaken on the advice of the ISC. It is essential that political chicanery not be correlated with the public interest. At the same time, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that appropriate protection is provided to an individual by only allowing disclosure of information that relates to the private affairs of an individual where such disclosure would not be unreasonable in the circumstances. The ISC is currently able to disclose information to the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Securities Commission. These amendments will allow the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to receive information obtained by the ISC. The effective operation of the tribunal which also commenced on 1 July 1994 can only be improved by these amendments. Keeping in mind the Privacy Act and the need to ensure individual privacy, where the ISC does hand information over to the tribunal this should only occur where the person concerned has given the ISC written authorisation. The disclosure of information to the tribunal should only be done where authority to do so has been given because it protects the privacy of the person concerned and it protects the ISC against any possible future dispute as to whether it was reasonable to disclose the information. Division 15 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure consistency between related provisions in the act which deal with the purposes for which an approved deposit fund may be maintained, and payments to beneficiaries also. This clarifies the existing obligation. The SI(S) Act currently restricts disqualified persons from being trustees or investment managers of superannuation entities. There is, however, no similar requirement on custodians. Division 17 of the bill amends the SI(S) Act to address this problem and ensure that custodians are subject to similar eligibility requirements to those applying to trustees and to investment managers. Naturally, custodians play an important role in safeguarding the assets of their clients in their contractual relationships with a trustee or an investment manager. It is more important that these sorts of prudential controls extend to custodians. Division 18 deals with the removal of trustees of public offer entities in section 60A. The bill inserts a new requirement into this SI(S) Act to prevent another party from trying to exert undue influence on a trustee by threatening to remove the trustee unless the trustee complies with that party's requests. This should serve to reinforce the perceived and intended real 2604 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 independence of trustees by requiring that the government rules of public offer funds allow a trustee to be removed only by the commissioner, unless the removal is of a kind to be specified in later regulations. Division 18A requires the trustees of an exempt public sector superannuation scheme that is subject to the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act to set up arrangements for dealing with inquiries or complaints. Clauses 50 to 52 enable regulations to be made bringing currently exempt public sector superannuation schemes within the operation of the S(RC) Act. This also is a welcome measure. It will increase the accessibility of the tribunal by public sector fund members and ensure that those funds that elect to become subject to the SI(S) Act have an internal resolution mechanism. This latest amendment rectifies an earlier problem. Previously, if a fund did not have an internal resolution mechanism a member could not go to the tribunal. Clauses 50 to 52 allow state and territory governments to legislate to subject their public superannuation schemes to the operations of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Ultimately, the decision to do so rests with the states, although to date I believe only Victoria and New South Wales have opted to stay out. Mr Deputy Speaker, superannuation policy under Labor has been a litany of wasted opportunities. The very rapidity of legislative changes to superannuation policy has created uncertainty where stability should exist. Superannuation is not as widely accepted as it should be as the preferred vehicle for retirement saving. Management fees, taxes levied on moneys going into and out of funds, the legislative uncertainty and the lack of choice of superannuation schemes have led to many people challenging the worth of superannuation as it is now constituted. The superannuation guarantee charge, the SGC, continues to be a major concern for employers. Imposing the costs of the SGC predominantly on employers is an impost that cannot be afforded. For every employer, the SGC is another hefty payroll tax that discourages investment in Australia and impacts negatively on possible future job creation. If the SGC exists to fund the retirement of an employer's employees, why should the employer foot the retirement bill? It is a social matter. Employees should also bear responsibility for their own superannuation contributions. Only by contributing towards the cost of their own retirement will employees realise the cost involved and gain an appreciation of the ownership of their future retirement income. Of course, there is the additional impost of complying with the SGC. This is just another cost that is added to the already long list of costs incurred over and above the total wages hill. Superannuation provides one method by which Australians can maximise our national savings. The government is in total disarray when it comes to a savings policy. The FitzGerald report on national savings advocated several necessary changes to government policy on superannuation that would assist in increasing the rate of savings. FitzGerald recommended, amongst other things, superannuation savings accounts and increased competition between the current players and, of course, future players. At the last election, the coalition advocated the establishment of retirement savings accounts. These accounts would have enjoyed the same superannuation tax concessions that we were advocating for superannuation policies. Our objective in advocating retirement savings accounts was twofold: to expand the range of choice available to individuals and to allow banks and other financial institutions to compete with superannuation funds in the provision of Thursday, 20 October 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 2605 superannuation schemes. These savings accounts would also have been available to low income and seasonal workers, thereby maintaining the tax office as the collector of government revenue, not as the manager of superannuation accounts. Greater competition in the provision of superannuation is anathema to Labor and the reasons are crystal clear: Labor is looking after its mates. Rather than introducing greater competition to the provision of superannuation, the government has closed the door on greater competition in order to protect existing super funds and, particularly, the role of the ACTU in occupational superannuation. The ACTU has been a constant opponent of greater competition and seems, once again, to have exercised its veto. To date, the ACTU has won all the battles, leaving the community as the loser. To the ACTU and this government, it seems superannuation has little to do with retirement income policy, and more to do with industrial relations and taxation. The drive for award based superannuation has taken little, if any, account of productivity. It takes no account of a firm's capacity to pay, and it denies individuals the right to best decide where their superannuation contributions should go. Nearly all award based superannuation contributions are paid into union dominated superannuation funds. The award based superannuation system is made worse because of the number of awards that cover many occupational groupings. These numerous superannuation schemes all have different conditions and obligations which must be met by employers. This makes the cost of complying with the superannuation guarantee all that much higher. Prior to Labor coming to power in March 1983, there were no taxes on contributions and fund earnings, and tax was only payable on five per cent of an individual's lump sum entitlement at the individual's marginal rate. There are now six taxes on superannuation that tax employer contributions, super fund investment income, the lump sums of those individuals under 55 years, ad infinitum. Superannuation has become Labor's milch cow. Labor's approach is simple: if it moves, tax it. This approach to retirement incomes has discouraged and confused many people about the benefits of superannuation. For individuals to fully fund their retirement, they need more than just the superannuation guarantee. They also need the desire to make their own contributions. By discouraging individual superannuation contributions, the government is actively discouraging the community from saving for retirement. In the Financial Review of 17 August this year, Barrie Dunstan wrote: Governments, as well as consumers, may need educating, considering that research group Mintel has found that, relative to many European countries, the level of targeted retirement income here is low. Taking the Australian level of retirement income from government pensions and privately financed savings as the base of 100, Mintel's figures put the relative welfare index of Italy at 196, Spain at 186, Sweden at 162 and Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg at 147. It is obvious that the governments of those countries are encouraging a much higher rate of retirement income for their citizens. Of course, this will also have the potential of translating into higher rates of national savings. The coalition will announce a revised superannuation policy, in the lead-up to the next election, that will try to come to grips with many of these issues. It will not necessarily mirror that of the 1993 election, but it will be committed to increasing the flexibility of the superannuation system and reducing the compliance costs of businesses. As I stated earlier, 2606 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 October 1994 the coalition does not oppose this bill as it is largely a housekeeping measure that, we have been pleased to note, was drafted in consultation with industry groups.
